STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 26, 2024
Jamie L Lemay
MARQUETTE/ALGER/SCHOOLCRAFT MDHHS
234 W BARAGA AVE,
MARQUETTE, MI, 49855-4710
RE: License#: CP520201281
Dear Jamie L Lemay:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 05/24/24. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
• (1) An agency shall have a written foster
parent/agency agreement signed by the
foster parent and the agency before initially
certifying a foster home for licensure.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not have a current parent/agency
agreement signed at the time of licensure.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents,
as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every
90 calendar days thereafter.
One of three files reviewed contained a late USP.
Repeat violation established:
2023 Interim, CAP approved 08/28/23.

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker
must obtain signatures from the following
individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line
supervisor, when siblings in care are placed apart. •
Parents who are a member of a participating
household. • Youth ages 14 and older. • Foster
parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers
One of three files reviewed contained a treatment plan that was signed more than
thirty days from the date of the service plan. Therefore, the signature page was
not uploaded into the electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
Repeat violation established:
2023 Interim, CAP approved 08/28/23.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
the electronic case management record using the
FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the
FTM.
One of three files reviewed documented a late service plan FTM. The file also
documented an FTM that occurred more than thirty days from the service plan
due date.
One of three files reviewed did not document an DHS-1105 for an FTM.
Repeat violation established:
2023 Interim, CAP approved 08/28/23.

FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
At least one contact each month must take place in
the child’s placement setting.
One of three files reviewed did not document an in home contact for April 2024.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 400.12415 (a) Incident reports. Discussed the requirement that
incidents reports are to be submitted to the consultant. Only those incidents
named under the rule are to be submitted.
• DCWL review of CAPS. The agency was informed that starting January 1,
2024, interim and renewal audit CAP's will be reviewed with the agency at
three months and six months. The assigned Consultant for the agency will
work with the agency in conducting CAP reviews. This process for special
investigation CAP reviews was implemented previously.
V. CONSULTATION
• Consultation was not requested or required at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows:
The agency Interim Inspection was completed on July 12, 2023 and an approved
CAP was received on August 28, 2023. The agency was cited for 5 violations, 3 of
which were repeated this year during the current renewal inspection. Two of the
repeat violations were consistent in the number of individual incidents, for
example, one late report occurred in the 2023 inspection and one late report in the
current renewal inspection. The other two repeat violations also had an equal
number of incidents from the 2023 inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The assessment did not
identify any barriers to maintaining compliance with rules and policy. The
assessment detailed tools being used by agency supervisors and administrators to
obtain compliance. The agency works closely with the MITEAM Analyst and
reviews MMR reports. The agency staff utilize the BOB to assist in achieving
compliance with standards.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted with three staff in person at the agency. Staff
reported feeling supported by their supervisors. Staff reported that their supervisor
and team members are available to assist as needed and there is a solid
supportive foster care team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is located in the Marquette County building. The agency maintains
sufficient office space and is well maintained. CHRI documents were secured, and
a cross shredder was available.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst identified two safety alerts.
Safety Alert #1. A bedroom in the basement of the home has two doorways and
one is without a door. A draped curtain covers the door.
Resolution: The agency initiated a special investigation to address the lack of an
installed bedroom door.

Safety Alert #2. This safety alert is part two of Safety Alert #1.
Resolution: The agency has requested a variance while FIG funding is being
applied for. Scheduled maintenance has been initiated to construct a door frame.
There currently are no foster children living in the home.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
June 25, 2024
_____________________________________
Douglas Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 26, 2024
_____________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
